header.title: An ABC of Witchcraft Past and Present

central_thesis: Doreen Valiente's central thesis asserts that modern witchcraft is the direct continuation of an ancient, pre-Christian 'Old Religion' of Western Europe, fundamentally distinct from Satanism or black magic. She argues that this tradition, centered on nature worship, fertility, and specific deities (the Horned God and Moon Goddess), survived underground through centuries of persecution and has experienced a modern renaissance. The book aims to demystify witchcraft, presenting it as a legitimate spiritual path and practical magical system rooted in perennial philosophy, emphasizing self-development and harmony with nature.

structure_content.summary: Valiente updates the context of modern witchcraft, highlighting its growth in the USA (feminist goddess-worship, national organizations like The Covenant of the Goddess), recognition as a religion, and Gerald Gardner's foundational role. She notes the increasing diversity of practices and the ongoing need to defend civil liberties against opposition from evangelical sects. The author discusses challenges to traditional coven hierarchy and the evolving nature of witchcraft as a 'living tradition'.

Valiente declares her personal bias as a practicing witch, asserting that witchcraft is the 'Old Religion' of Western Europe, predating and distinct from Abrahamic faiths. She describes its core tenets: worship of the Horned God and Moon Goddess, organization into thirteen-member covens, monthly Esbats and eight yearly Sabbats (including solstices and equinoxes). Rituals involve dancing, chanting, meditation, magic circles, athames, incense, and often ritual nudity, all aimed at raising 'power' and communing with nature's forces. The author differentiates witchcraft from black magic and Satanism, emphasizing its ancient roots and rejection of man-made dogmas.

Explores the ancient, magical origins of alphabets beyond mere record-keeping. It discusses Hebrew Qabalah, Celtic Ogham, and Runic alphabets, noting their esoteric meanings and numerical values. The Theban Alphabet is highlighted as a favorite among witches for concealing secrets and enhancing concentration, thereby boosting magical potency.

Defines amulets as magical objects designed to repel danger and evil, distinct from talismans which attract benefit. Examples include cyclamen, amber, horse-brasses, blue beads, and specific hand gestures (mano infica, mano cornuta). Valiente stresses their ancient origins, psychological efficacy, and the importance of consecration for potency.

Traces witchcraft's origins to the Stone Age, evident in cave art depicting hunting and fertility magic, leading to the worship of the Naked Goddess and the Horned God. It connects these deities to Ancient Greek and Roman figures like Hecate and Apuleius' descriptions of witches. Valiente argues that witchcraft represents the enduring pre-Christian matriarchal religion, suppressed and demonized by the patriarchal Christian Church, but surviving as a 'deep thing' appealing to the human soul.

Discusses Charles Godfrey Leland's 1899 work 'Aradia: or the Gospel of the Witches' as a crucial text demonstrating the survival of the 'Old Religion' into modern times. It outlines Aradia's cosmogony, where Diana, the primordial goddess, divides herself into darkness and light (Lucifer). Diana sends her daughter Aradia to earth to teach witchcraft to the oppressed, including rituals of naked feasting and spells to influence love, fortune, and health, and to curse enemies.

Describes the black-handled knife as the traditional witch's weapon, primarily used for drawing the magic circle and controlling spirits. Its ancient prototypes include daggers seen in Greek art associated with moon goddesses and magical grimoires (Clavicle of Solomon's Arthana). The text highlights its symbolic evolution as a tool of magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: ATHO, A NAME OF THE HORNED GOD
structure_content.summary: Presents Atho as a specific carved head of the Horned God, owned by Raymond Howard. It details its primitive artistic qualities, bulls' horns, zodiacal and pentagrammatic ornamentation, and symbols of fertility. The name Atho is linked to the Old Welsh 'Arddhu' (The Dark One), emphasizing the deity's ancient British roots and its personification of life and fertility. The head's theft and the mystery surrounding it are noted.

Outlines fundamental witch beliefs: the reality of magic, human psychic capacities beyond five senses, and a divine concept that is both masculine and feminine, embodying the 'Life-force of the universe'. The moral code is 'Do what you will, so long as it harms none,' emphasizing self-responsibility rather than fixed rules. Reincarnation and the 'Land of Faery' are discussed as post-death realms. The inherent 'power of thought' in magic is a key concept, supported by historical anecdotes like 'The Wicche, the Bagge and the Bisshop'.

Clarifies that the Black Mass is a perversion of a Christian sacrament, not a genuine witchcraft rite. It originated from a revolt against Church oppression, where 'evil' acts like sexual enjoyment were embraced to defy Christian dogma. True witchcraft, being pagan, has its own traditions, including wine and cakes consecrated to the Horned God and Moon Goddess, distinct from the blasphemous nature of the Black Mass. The naked woman on the altar in a Black Mass is interpreted as a distorted remnant of the ancient worship of the Great Goddess.

Describes ritual bonfires as a favored pagan method for celebrating the eight Celtic Great and Lesser Sabbats, such as Candlemas, May Eve, Lammas, and Halloween. These fires served practical (warmth, cooking for gatherings) and magical (naked dances, blessing crops, need-fire for sickness, ashes for luck) purposes. The practice highlights the deep connection between pagan festivals, nature cycles, and community rites, often disguised in later Christianized forms.

Explains the 'Book of Shadows' as the personal grimoire of modern witches, containing rituals, invocations, and charms, traditionally copied and individualized. The practice of burning the book upon a witch's death ensured secrecy and protected families from persecution. Symbolically, its contents are seen as a 'shadow of the realities of the Other World,' emphasizing the hidden, mystical nature of magic and spirits.

Examines the broomstick's role as a traditional witch companion and magical conveyance, linking it to phallic symbolism and fertility. It notes its appearance in folklore, irregular marriage ceremonies ('jump the besom'), and older slang terms with sexual connotations. The traditional woods used for brooms (birch, ash, osier willow) are also discussed for their magical meanings, highlighting the deep-rooted, ancient symbolism of this common object.

This 10th-century document is presented as the official Church teaching on witchcraft for centuries, describing witches as deluded heretics who worship 'Diana, the goddess of the pagans,' and whose supposed night flights are mere hallucinations induced by the Devil. Valiente stresses that this view contrasts sharply with later demonological dogma (e.g., 'Malleus Maleficarum') that portrayed witches as active devil-worshippers, providing early evidence of Diana's worship in surviving pagan cults.

Details the popular belief in cats, especially black cats, as witch familiars, connecting it to ancient Egyptian cat worship (Bast/Isis) and their 'magical' and 'uncanny' qualities. It discusses the cat's nocturnal habits, moon-like eyes, and static electricity as contributing to their sinister reputation. Valiente mentions the Devil sometimes appearing as a black cat and how cats are believed to possess psychic perceptions and even astral projection abilities.

Explores the cauldron as a significant symbol in witchcraft, tracing its origins to ancient Greek witches (Medea) and Celtic myths (Cauldron of Inspiration and Rebirth, associated with the goddess Cerridwen). It represents the feminine principle, transformation, and regeneration of Nature. The evolution of the cauldron into the Holy Grail legend is noted, highlighting its deep symbolic meaning beyond the popular 'witches' brew' image.

Examines prehistoric cave art as evidence of early religious and magical practices, particularly hunting and fertility magic. It describes figures of wounded animals (sympathetic magic) and female fertility figures ('Venus figures'), and the 'Sorcerer' or Horned God with antlers. Valiente argues these motifs represent the ancient deities of witchcraft and that the round dance of women (e.g., Cogul) depicts early witch rituals, justifying the claim of witchcraft as the world's oldest religion.

Explains the magic circle as a fundamental, ancient, and worldwide occult practice. It symbolizes infinity, eternity, and serves to protect the operator while concentrating raised power ('Cone of Power'). The circle is oriented to cardinal points, with movements typically 'deasil' (sunwise) for positive magic and 'tuathal' (widdershins) for adverse. Construction involves an athame, an altar, and often incorporates pentagrams between inner and outer circles. Ancient Assyrian and Indian parallels are noted, linking it to universal archetypes like the mandala.

Describes the Cotswolds as a historical center of witchcraft, citing the 1945 'Witchcraft Murder' on Meon Hill and the now-closed witchcraft museum. It details how places like the Rollright Stones (a prehistoric stone circle) were traditional meeting places for witches, particularly on May Eve. The author shares a personal anecdote of encountering a woman performing a ritual dance at the King Stone, highlighting the persistence of pagan practices.

Details the traditional coven size of thirteen (six men, six women, and a leader), noting that covens divide if exceeding this number to ensure continuation of the Craft. Old witch laws mandated distance between covens and secrecy, leading to the use of 'eke-names' during persecution. Valiente distinguishes between a fertility coven (thirteen, for life powers) and a magical coven (eight, for higher consciousness), also acknowledging individual witches who work alone after coven training.

Explains why crossroads have been traditional meeting places for witches since ancient times, linking them to Diana Trivia (goddess of the three ways) and Hecate (triple moon goddess). The custom of burying suicides and executed criminals at crossroads, denying Christian burial, further associated these sites with pagan powers. Specific British examples like Wych Cross and Wilverley Post are cited.

Analyzes Aleister Crowley's place in occultism, emphasizing he was a Qabalistic magician (practicing 'white Magick') rather than a witch, and his distrust of women. The summary covers his Thelemic philosophy ('Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law. Love is the Law, love under Will') from 'Liber Legis' and the concept of the 'Aeon of Horus'. It touches upon his flamboyant personality, controversies (e.g., 'Wickedest Man in the World'), and the negative impact on some followers, noting his works' reprinting and continued relevance.

Discusses dancing as an inherently magical activity in primitive cultures and witchcraft, used for enjoyment, ritual, and raising power. Examples include imitative magic (leaping for crops), round dances around individuals or objects (trees, bonfires) to direct 'Cone of Power,' and spiral dances ('Troy Town') for exploring the Other World. Valiente suggests witch dances (e.g., La Volta) may have influenced modern dance, inducing light hypnosis or ecstasy, making them a core attraction of the Old Religion.

Profiles Dr. John Dee as a prominent English occultist, mathematician, and alchemist. It highlights his work with Edward Kelley in developing the Enochian language for communication with 'angels,' emphasizing its complex nature and the need for prudence in its use. The text also mentions Dee's role as Queen Elizabeth I's secret agent ('007') and his interest in the Glastonbury Zodiac, underscoring his blend of scientific and esoteric pursuits.

Examines demonology as the Church's classification of demons, positing that all rival cults and witchcraft were inspired by Satan. Valiente critiques this view, arguing that the Hebrew 'Satan' means 'adversary' and that 'the Devil' (as defined by Eliphas Levi) is a 'Devil of God' or personification of blind natural forces. It touches upon the Book of Enoch and the 'fallen angels' story, suggesting an extraterrestrial origin for these traditions, and discusses grimoires like 'The Goetia' for commanding spirits.

Argues that the Devil, as a personified evil, is a later Christian construct. Valiente traces the conventional horned, hoofed image of the Devil to the pagan god Pan and the ancient Horned God, whose cults were suppressed and demonized by the Church. She points out that many British place-names and old buildings attributed to the Devil actually refer to pre-Christian deities or extraordinary natural features, representing the untamed forces of nature and human desire, projected as 'sinful' by the Church.

Describes the 'Devil's Mark' as a supposed indelible sign placed on a witch at initiation, believed by witch-hunters to be insensitive to pain and unable to bleed. The text details the practices of witch-prickers in Scotland using trick bodkins and exploiting natural peculiarities (like Anne Boleyn's extra nipple) to secure convictions. Valiente dismisses these as superstitious fears, noting the financial motivation behind witch-hunting and its eventual suppression.

Explores Diana as the Roman moon goddess, identified with the Greek Artemis and Hecate, and revered as a triple goddess (waxing, full, waning moon). She is presented as the 'Queen of Witches' in Italy, with Leland's 'Aradia' offering evidence of her cult's survival. The text details her attributes (huntress, great mother, childbirth patroness) and links her to various pagan names (Herodias, Abundia, Nicneven). Diana's association with London (London Stone, St. Paul's Cathedral site) and the sacrifice of horned beasts highlights the persistence of pagan rites into Christian times.

Discusses foxglove as a plant traditionally associated with witches, known as 'witches' glove' or 'witches' thimble'. The text highlights Dr. William Withering's discovery of its medicinal properties from a village 'witch-wife,' demonstrating the practical knowledge within traditional 'wortcunning.' This underscores that traditional witch lore was not mere superstition but contained valuable herbal wisdom.

Defines divination as foretelling the future or discovering hidden things by magical means, an ancient and integral part of witchcraft. It covers various methods: seeing pictures in fire, listening to wind, tea-cup reading, crystal-gazing (scrying), I Ching, Tarot cards, geomancy. Valiente emphasizes that clairvoyance involves quietness, attunement to nature's subtle forces, and interpreting symbols (both universal and individual). The importance of concentration and the role of psychic perception in gaining insights are stressed.

Describes the Dorset Ooser as a curious horned mask connected to the 'Old Religion' and the Horned God. Historically worn at Christmas revels as the 'Christmas Bull', its name is linked to the Old English 'Os' (god). The mask's disappearance and a local tradition of pagan customs persisting despite Church condemnation are highlighted, illustrating the enduring influence of ancient beliefs in regional folklore.

Connects Sir Francis Drake to the witch cult in Devonshire, noting legends of him invoking rituals to defeat the Spanish Armada. He is depicted as a leader of the Wild Hunt and a spirit whose soul cannot rest due to practicing witchcraft. The 'Devil's Point' headland near Plymouth is identified as a site where Drake allegedly foregathered with witches to raise storms, illustrating the deep integration of witchcraft into regional folklore.

Explores the elusive links between Druidism and witchcraft, noting the existence of Druidesses. Valiente posits that both traditions share a common origin in ancient nature worship. Key connections include the sacred Cauldron of Inspiration (Cerridwen), belief in reincarnation (Abred, Gwynvyd), and the celebration of the eight major Sabbats (Beltane, Lughnasadh, Samhain, Imbolc) identical to Druidic festivals. The worship of Hu Gadarn, a horned god, and the survival of pagan practices like the Darvellgadarn image into Christian times further strengthen these links.

Discusses potential historical connections between European witchcraft and Eastern occult traditions. It highlights two main contact points: Moorish Spain (Toledo as a magic center) and the Knights Templars (accused of Baphomet worship, possibly influenced by Sufi concepts). The chapter introduces the Dhulqarneni cult (Two-Horned Lord, moon worship, ritual knives, forked staffs) and the concept of 'baraka' (blessing/power), suggesting an exchange of ideas between East and West, potentially dating back to Neolithic migrations from North Africa.

Describes the traditional occult classification of nature spirits into four groups aligned with the Four Elements: gnomes (earth), undines (water), sylphs (air), and salamanders (fire). The use of the pentagram for controlling these elementals is mentioned, along with the names of elemental kings. This concept underscores the magical worldview where spirits inhabit various natural domains, accessible through specific magical practices.

Defines the Esbat as the monthly coven meeting, held at the full moon for practical and enjoyable purposes, including specific coven business, magical work, or social gathering. Ritual attire (black cloak and hood) serves for camouflage and symbolic secrecy. Activities include dancing, invoking Old Gods, feasting, consecrating magical objects, divination, ceremonial joining of partners, and baby presentations to the Old Gods, emphasizing its local and less solemn nature compared to Sabbats.

Explores the widespread, ancient belief in the Evil Eye, describing it as the malicious glance of envious individuals that can cause sickness or misfortune. Valiente details various amulets used for protection, such as blue beads, the Hand of Fatima, and specific hand gestures (mano cornuta, mano in fica). Other remedies include twisting knots, out-staring representations (Eye of Horus), and reflecting 'witch-balls.' The psychological impact of belief and the cultural universality of this phenomenon are emphasized.

Distinguishes evocation (compelling lower spirits into a magical triangle) from invocation (calling higher spirits or gods into a magic circle). It describes grimoire-based rituals for evocation, involving specific words of power (Hebrew, Greek), sigils, and a censer with aromatic herbs to provide a physical form for the spirit. Valiente emphasizes that the true potency lies in the 'Astral fluid' and the magician's will, noting the practice's inherent dangers.

Examines the close relationship between witchcraft and the 'world of Faerie,' suggesting fairies might be folk memories of aboriginal peoples ('Little People of the Hills') living in secret, often nude, and possessing heathen magic. Stories from Scottish witch trials link witches with fairies, describing them as spiritual beings, capable of changing habitations, and seen during the Celtic 'quarters of the year.' Valiente connects the Queen of Elphame, the high priestess of a coven, to these fairy traditions.

Categorizes witch familiars into three types: discarnate human spirits, non-human elementals (which may indwell objects like crystals), and material creatures (cats, ferrets, toads). Witches form a psychic link with their familiars, sometimes by offering a drop of blood or milk. Familiars are used for divination (selecting objects) and conveying magical influence. The chapter details the intelligence and psychic abilities of toads, their 'milk' containing bufotenin (a hallucinogen), and historical cases of familiars like Rutterkin the cat.

Explains the deep, fundamental importance of fertility worship in ancient cultures due to short life expectancies and high infant mortality. It describes fertility as the 'Life itself' and notes that rituals, including sexual acts ('hieros gamos'), were performed to align with universal life forces ('as above, so below'). The author argues that rural pagans maintained these rites, which were later seen as 'crude' by refined classes. Modern witches continue this tradition, focusing on vitality and harmony with nature, extending the concept of fertility to mind and soul, and rejecting promiscuity while upholding sex's sacredness.

Discusses fire, particularly candlelight, as a perpetual accompaniment to magical ceremonies, enhancing psychic results and transforming the commonplace into the uncanny. Colored candles are used for specific magical purposes (red for life, black for departed spirits), and witches often craft their own beeswax candles with herbs and pentagrams. The flame is used for communication with spirits (flickering), and bonfires replace candles outdoors. The blueish light observed during rituals is linked to Wilhelm Reich's 'orgone energy', a universal cosmic power. Concentration on the flame aids clairvoyance and focus for wishes.

Investigates the traditional witch's ability to fly, attributed to trance-inducing ointments rather than physical flight. Valiente cites historical sources like Francis Bacon and Giovanni Battista Porta, detailing ingredients such as smallage, wolfsbane, hemlock, mandrake, henbane, and poplar leaves, often mixed with 'children's fat' (a horrific but likely symbolic ingredient). She discusses Dr. Erich-Will Peuckert's experiment, where applying such unguents induced hallucinogenic visions of flying and orgiastic Sabbats, suggesting a pharmacological basis for these legendary experiences.

Explores the use of striking and mysterious fossils as charms in witchcraft, linking them to ancient magical practices. Examples include ammonites ('snake stones'), fossilized sea urchins ('shepherd's crowns,' 'fairy loaves') for luck and protection against lightning, witchcraft, and the Evil Eye. The 'Sussex witch stone' (fossil sponge) and belemnites (phallic symbols) are also mentioned. Jet and amber, being fossilized, were highly valued for their electrical properties and protective qualities against witchcraft and melancholy.

Acknowledges Gerald Gardner as the catalyst for the modern, worldwide revival of witchcraft. Valiente, who knew him, highlights his Scottish descent, numerological significance of his birth (13, 4), and lifelong interest in the occult, nurtured during his time in the East. His initial contact with British witchcraft in the New Forest, through a coven associated with the Rosicrucian Fellowship of Crotona, is detailed. Gardner's decision to publicize the Craft after the Witchcraft Act's repeal in 1951, despite coven elders' desire for secrecy, is presented as a controversial but pivotal act to prevent the Old Religion from dying out, though his 'Gardnerian' version incorporated his own ideas and Masonic elements.

Examines the garter's significance as a mark of rank among witches, tracing its importance through historical accounts and folklore. Valiente discusses Margaret Murray's theory that the Order of the Garter's foundation (by King Edward III) has its roots in the Old Religion, with the dropped garter symbolizing a leading witch's revealed status. A 16th-century wood-engraving depicting a witch binding her leg with a garter before flying further illustrates its traditional magical association.

Describes the Green Man as a recurring motif in medieval art, representing the spirit of trees and woodlands, often depicted as a human face surrounded by foliage, sometimes horned. Valiente highlights his pagan origins as a woodland god, whose presence in Christian churches (roof bosses, misericords) signifies the peaceful coexistence of pagan and Christian concepts in Britain for centuries. Folk customs like 'Green Jack' or 'Garland King' are presented as survivals of this nature deity, with green being a 'witch's colour'.

Establishes a close relationship between gypsies and witches, citing a proverb: 'Wherever the Romanies go, there witches may be found.' Gypsies are presented as carriers of magic, skilled in fortune-telling (palmistry, Tarot cards), and sharing a belief in reincarnation and the Great Mother (Amari De, Sara-Kali). Their outdoor gatherings with cauldrons and dancing are noted as resembling witches' Sabbats, suggesting mutual protection and interchange of ideas between these outcast groups against Christian society. The Romany word 'Devel' for God is linked to the Sanskrit 'Deva' ('shining one').

Explains Halloween (October 31st) as a Great Sabbat and a traditional ghostly season when spirits roam. It traces the festival to the Celtic Eve of Samhain ('Summer's End'), marking the beginning of winter and originally celebrated with ritual bonfires by Druids to burn away anxieties. Modern Halloween customs (dressing up, pumpkin lanterns, spooky frolics) are seen as direct descendants of these ancient rites, which witches used as cover for meetings and as symbolic scaring devices against intruders. The author notes the Church's attempt to Christianize it as All Saints Day.

Details various hauntings attributed to witchcraft, often linked to the lingering presence of a witch's familiar spirits, particularly after a violent death. O'Donnell's accounts include a black bird (witch's pet), phantom cats, mice, and a spectral animal from an elm tree. The text emphasizes that places where magical rites have been performed can retain a 'field of force,' attracting spirits and elementals. The documented haunting of Major Thomas Weir's house in Edinburgh, with sounds of dancing and spinning, is cited as a direct connection to a famous witchcraft case.

Presents Hecate as the Ancient Greek goddess of witchcraft, predating Olympian deities, and revered for her threefold power over heaven, earth, and the underworld. Her symbols include a key (releasing spirits) and her association with crossroads as meeting places for witches. Valiente links Hecate to the moon's triplicity (waxing, full, waning) and her companions, howling dogs. Gnostic and Chaldean Oracles identify her as the Great Mother or 'Life of the universe.' Her ancient title, 'one hundred,' connects her to the Great Year and the sacrificial Sacred King, establishing her profound, ancient significance in pagan beliefs.

Explores the extensive knowledge of herbs ('wortcunning') possessed by witches, encompassing both medicinal and occult properties. The text discusses the Greek 'pharmakeia' (drugs/potions), historical herbals (Dioscorides, Pliny, Culpeper), and the village witch's role as healer, midwife, and psychologist. Magical uses include mugwort for clairvoyance, mullein ('hag-taper'), foxglove ('witches' bells'), periwinkle ('sorcerers' violet'), satyrion (orchid) for love, and St. John's wort ('fuga demonum') and rowan for protection. The astrological timing of herb gathering (moon phases) is also highlighted.

Identifies various British hills as traditional sites for witchcraft gatherings, often possessing prehistoric sanctity. Examples include Pendle Hill (Lancashire) with May Day celebrations, Chanctonbury Ring (Sussex) as a Romano-British temple, Glastonbury Tor, and Bredon Hill (Gloucestershire) with its Bambury Stone. The text recounts mysterious deaths (Meon Hill) and ghostly phenomena (Stiperstones, Ditchling Beacon's Wild Hunt), linking these to pagan rites and the enduring belief in uncanny influences on high places.

Discusses holed stones as ancient amulets, valued by white witchcraft for protection and luck. Valiente explains their symbolism as a 'female emblem' representing the 'portal of birth' and a 'life symbol.' They are also known as 'hag stones,' used against nightmares and witches riding horses. The text mentions a belief in seeing fairies through them and Leland's 'Aradia' linking them to Diana's favor, highlighting their widespread and enduring magical significance.

Exposes Matthew Hopkins, the self-appointed 'Witch-Finder General' (1644-1646), as a notorious figure responsible for hundreds of executions, driven by financial gain. Valiente details his cruel methods of extracting 'confessions' from vulnerable victims, such as stripping, sleep deprivation, and 'swimming' tests (tying thumbs to toes and throwing into water). The text mentions his use of trick bodkins and sale of 'witch boxes' for protection, highlighting the public's eventual disgust and his own controversial death. It contextualizes his reign of terror within the disordered times of the English Civil War.

Explores the Horned God as a universal, ancient deity, tracing his worship from Stone Age cave art (ithyphallic figures) to Egyptian (Ammon-Ra), Minoan Crete, and Celtic (Cernunnos) traditions. Horns symbolize power and virility. Valiente explains how the Christian Church demonized this deity, equating him with the Devil, particularly in witches' Sabbats. The Horned God represents the masculine, active side of Nature, controlling life and death, and his cult involved bull-leaping, ram worship, and ritual disguise, signifying his enduring grassroots antiquity as a fertility god.

Discusses the profound connection between horses and magic in pre-motorized societies. Horses, being sensitive animals, were believed to be susceptible to bewitchment, leading to folk beliefs like 'hag-ridden.' Charms such as holed stones and horse brasses were used for protection. The 'Society of the Horseman's Word' in Scotland, with its secret initiations and knowledge of herbs to influence horses, illustrates a practical, occult side to this lore. Valiente explains that the horseshoe, a symbol of the moon goddess, offered protection against witchcraft, showcasing the deep integration of magic in rural life.

Reveals that hypnosis, under various names, has been a secret magical technique since ancient times, used by witches to induce trances and achieve magical effects. Valiente explains how post-hypnotic suggestion could be used for healing (e.g., casting childbirth pains onto animals) and manipulation. The village witch's use of occult props and shrewd observation to overawe visitors is highlighted. Dr. James Braid's scientific discovery of hypnosis is linked to traditional witch methods, such as gazing at bright objects or 'witch balls,' demonstrating the natural basis of these 'supernatural' powers.

Explores the fundamental magical principle that an image or likeness can influence the represented person or animal. Valiente provides historical examples from Ancient Egypt (wax images against Pharaoh Rameses III), Queen Elizabeth I's court (wax image with pin), and Scottish witch trials (Mother Demdike's clay pictures for killing). She details the creation and use of 'mommets' (wax/clay effigies) for curses or love spells, emphasizing the witch's concentrated thought as the driving force. Modern manifestations, like 'voodoo dolls' and archaeological finds of thorn-pierced objects, illustrate the enduring belief in sympathetic magic.

Details the ancient and widespread use of incense in religious and magical rites, tracing its origins to Ancient Egypt. Valiente explains its three main purposes: carrying prayers, pleasing unseen powers, and influencing the human mind through scent to create a magical atmosphere. She describes two types of incense (joss sticks/cones, charcoal-burned gum-resins), their preparation, and proper use in magic circles. The text suggests that experimenting with different perfumes can reveal their astrological correspondences and psychological effects, valuing practical experience over 'booklarnin'.

Examines the ancient, worldwide belief in sexual intercourse between spiritual beings and mortals. Valiente explains how, under Christianity, these beings (incubus for women, succubus for men) were demonized. She discusses medieval Church debates on their nature and the possibility of conception with demons, linking it to the 'Antichrist' theme in 'Rosemary's Baby'. Historical confessions of witches describe the Devil's 'icy coldness,' which Murray attributes to ritual disguise and artificial phalli. The author suggests that such experiences were often hallucinatory, drug-induced, or rooted in erotic dreams, highlighting a modern case of obsession for sexual pleasure.

Explains witchcraft initiation as a core element of its underground organization, similar to other secret societies. It requires a solemn oath of loyalty and traditionally involves initiation by a person of the opposite sex, with exceptions for one's own children. Valiente notes the historical context of persecution, where secrecy was paramount, and blood relatives of convicted witches were suspect. Ritual acts like taking a new name, renouncing Christian baptism (e.g., trampling a cross), and ritual marking (oil, wine, pigment) are described, with modern practices adapting for safety and aesthetics (e.g., eye-shadow).

Differentiates invocation (calling higher spiritual beings/gods into the magic circle) from evocation (compelling lower spirits into a magical triangle). Valiente emphasizes that invocation aims to heighten the operator's consciousness to a spiritual state for working magic, often using sonorous 'words of power' from ancient languages (Greek, Latin, Hebrew) or poetic expressions (Crowley's 'Hymn to Pan'). She cites the Magical Papyrus and Ruteboeuf's play for historical examples and provides a modern invocation to the Moon Goddess, stressing the importance of the operator's inner state ('enflame thyself in praying').

Examines Janicot, an old Basque god, as a key clue to the 'Old Religion's' survival, as noted by Margaret Murray. Valiente details Pierre De Lancre's accounts of Basque witches using Janicot's name in place of Christian symbols and in rituals involving an 'Osculum infame' (kissing the Devil's buttocks), which she interprets as homage to the human representative of a pagan god. Janicot is linked to Roman deities Diana and Janus ('King of the Wood'), personifying life, death, and fertility. The survival of such practices, disguised or demonized, highlights the persistence of ancient paganism.

Analyzes the 1324 trial of Dame Alice Kyteler, Ireland's first major witch trial, as a historically significant case. Accused of poisoning, witchcraft, and sacrificing to 'Robert Artisson, the Devil,' she was supported by nobility, indicating a conflict between secular and ecclesiastical powers. Valiente describes the sympathetic magic (sweeping wealth), wafer with Devil's name, and greased staff for flight. The coven of thirteen, including Artisson (her human lover, not a spirit), and the use of torture to extract confessions (e.g., from Petronilla de Meath) are highlighted, showing early persecution tactics and the conflation of pagan deities with the Christian Devil.

Describes Lammas (August 1st) as one of the four Greater Sabbats, historically linked to the mysterious death of King William Rufus in the New Forest, which Margaret Murray interprets as a ritual sacrifice. The festival, derived from the Celtic Lughnasadh, honored the dead sun god, symbolizing death and rebirth at the turn of the agricultural year. Valiente notes the popular holiday aspect ('Gule of August') and the Welsh legend of Llew, a murdered king who returned to life, reinforcing the deep pagan significance of this Sabbat.

Details the historical progression of laws against witchcraft, noting that ancient laws distinguished black magic from white. Valiente highlights how, with Christianity, all non-Christian gods were demonized, leading to persecution based on heresy. Early English laws (Canute) forbade heathen customs, and the statute 'De Haeretico Comburendo' (1401) sanctioned burning. The text contrasts English hanging with Scottish/Continental burning (often preceded by strangulation for confession) and discusses the financial motives of witch-hunters like Matthew Hopkins. The Witchcraft Act of 1736 (imprisonment for pretending witchcraft) and its eventual repeal in 1951, due to Spiritualist efforts, mark the shift from capital punishment to recognizing psychic phenomena.

Presents Charles Godfrey Leland as a pivotal figure in folklore and witchcraft studies, authoring 'Gypsy Sorcery,' 'Etruscan-Roman Remains,' and 'Aradia.' Valiente highlights his role in documenting the 'Old Religion' of Italian witches (La Vecchio Religione), introduced by Maddalena, and his insights into Diana as the 'Queen of Witches.' Leland's personal occult practices, including invoking spirits for lost items and his ownership of a 'Black Stone of the Voodoos,' are mentioned. His work helped establish witchcraft as a subject for comparative religion and anthropology.

Examines Lilith as the moon goddess, an archetypal seductress and patroness of witches, distinct from Hecate as an 'enticing sorceress' or 'femme fatale.' Her ancient depiction (Sumer, ~2000 B.C.) with bird claws is noted. Jewish legends identify her as Adam's first wife, mother of uncanny beings like fairies and djinn, embodying erotic dreams. Valiente connects Lilith to Herodias and Aradia in Slavonian spells, highlighting her role in the 'witches' thirteen' and her personification of repressed erotic desires.

Explores the enduring belief in love charms across cultures and eras, from ancient Egyptian papyri to modern practices. Valiente discusses the psychological effects of belief and various ingredients, including 'lucky roots' (John the Conqueror Root, marsh St. John's wort) with phallic symbolism, aromatic herbs (verbena, musk, patchouli, orris root), and aphrodisiac foods (tomatoes, potatoes). The text details traditional spells like 'cockle-bread' (dough pressed against body) and the lamb bladebone ritual, illustrating the blend of magic and practical psychology. A 15th-century painting depicting a naked witch preparing a love charm emphasizes ritual nudity and symbolism.

Defines magic through various occult perspectives, including Aleister Crowley's 'Science and Art of causing Change to occur in conformity with Will' and S.L. MacGregor Mathers' 'Science of the Control of the Secret Forces of Nature.' Valiente stresses that magic works through natural forces, understood by penetrating nature's hidden side, not by miraculous violation. She differentiates black (misuse, blood sacrifice) from white magic, acknowledges its ancient origins (Greek 'Magike techne,' Persian Magi), and describes the magician as 'born' with psychic sensitivity, developed through study. The true purpose of magic, she concludes, is self-development and human evolution, not merely incidental powers.

Details the legends and factual properties of the mandrake root (Atropa mandragora), a plant linked to witchcraft and sorcery. Valiente describes its resemblance to a human figure ('homunculus'), its narcotic properties (man's oldest anesthetic), and the perilous ritual for digging it up (magic sword, wax in ears, hungry dog, horn blowing). The plant's nocturnal glow (due to glow-worms) and screaming legend are explained. The text mentions its historical use for magical purposes, often as a familiar spirit, and its modern use as a lucky charm, with English mandrake (briony) serving as a local substitute.

Analyzes Charles Manson and his 'family' in the context of the 1969 Hollywood ritual murders, linking them to black magic and Satanism. Valiente describes Manson's hypnotic influence over his followers, their drug use (LSD), and his self-perception as a Christ-Satan figure. His Scorpio birth-sign is discussed as correlating with his magnetic personality and dark tendencies. The text highlights the 'devil of a medieval witches' coven' archetype in Manson's behavior, and the use of 'witchy things' as signs, illustrating a modern, distorted manifestation of occult beliefs fueled by societal repression.

Traces moon worship to ancient times (Book of Job), highlighting the moon's feminine symbolism, rule over fertility, tides, and psychic energy. Valiente describes how moon phases influence human behavior, creating 'lunatics.' She explains the use of waxing and waning moon for constructive and destructive magic, respectively, and cites Bardic Triads for its 'beautiful' names. The moon goddess is presented as a deity of love, enchantment, and mystery, identified with Isis, Artemis, and Diana. The text links the moon to alchemical silver and the sacred number thirteen, emphasizing its enduring magical significance despite modern space travel.

Profiles Mother Shipton as a famous prophetess and witch from Knaresborough, born in 1488, with a traditional depiction including a black cat and forked broomstick. Her origin story involves her mother, Agatha Sontheil, and the Devil, who bestowed supernormal powers on Agatha. Valiente describes Ursula's (Mother Shipton's) childhood display of powers, her reputation as a seer, and her prophecies (e.g., Cardinal Wolsey's fall). The narrative connects her story to the 'male leader of a coven' as 'the Devil,' highlighting the persistent conflation of pagan deities with Christian evil.

Acknowledges Margaret Murray as a renowned scholar whose 'Witch Cult in Western Europe' (1921) championed the idea of witchcraft as an ancient, pre-Christian religion. Valiente describes Murray's life as an anthropologist and suffragette, including her investigation of the Meon Hill murder. Murray's interpretation of the Devil as a man in ritual disguise at Sabbats is central. The text also covers Murray's interest in telepathy and apparitions (ghosts as photographic images) and her belief in reincarnation, positioning her as a critical, yet sympathetic, researcher of occult traditions.

Explores ritual nudity as an ancient practice in magical and religious rites across various cultures (Pompeii, Old Testament prophets, gypsies, ancient Britain). Valiente explains its symbolic meaning as freedom, unity with nature, and a state of religious ecstasy, as commanded in 'Aradia.' She notes modern debates on its practicality in different climates and its potential to attract inappropriate attention. The text discusses historical artistic depictions of naked witches (Hans Baldung Grun, Albrecht Durer), arguing that the 'obscenity' is often in the eye of the beholder, and that genuine ritual nudity transcends mere sexual display.

Examines the occult significance of numbers in witchcraft and magic. The number thirteen is paramount (lunar months, Christ and twelve disciples), contrasting with its perception as unlucky (triskedekaphobia). Seven holds great importance (seventh son/daughter as witch, sacred planets, days of week, Biblical allusions, pagan sages), as do odd numbers generally. The concept of man as a triad or seven principles, Druidic Triads ('Tribann'), and 'climacteric years' are discussed. Magic squares (Kamea) are presented as powerful talismans, reflecting ancient mathematical and astrological co-relations in magical practice.

Analyzes 'The Old 'Un' as a dialect term for the Devil, arguing it refers to a degraded pre-Christian god whose characteristics didn't fit Christian deity. Valiente connects 'Old Harry' to Saxon 'hearh' (hill-top sanctuary) and 'Owd Providence' to ancient pagan powers. Other terms like 'Old Hornie' (Pan), 'Old Splitfoot' (cloven hoofs), 'Old Poker' (Puck), and 'Old Nick' (Woden) reveal the demonization of pagan deities. The chapter notes the Christianization of pagan sites (St. Nicholas churches) and the enduring association of Yule and other festivals with old fertility gods, showcasing persistent folk memories of ancient religion.

Describes palmistry (cheiromancy) as an ancient art of divination through hand-reading, with origins in India and study by Greeks (Aristotle). Valiente notes its medieval sanction by some churchmen and its association with astrology, linking the hand's features (mounts, lines, fingers) to planets and zodiacal signs (Venus, Jupiter, Saturn, Sun, Mercury, Moon, Mars). The text explains how palmists read inherited tendencies (left hand) and life's development (right hand). It mentions the power to 'know the secrets of the hand' as a witch's power and its eventual legalization after being considered witchcraft.

Presents Pan as the Greek goat-footed Horned God, whose name means 'All, everything,' embodying the positive Life Force of Nature. His attributes (fawn-skin as stars, shaggy hair as forest, horns as power) and his seven-reeded pipe (septenary nature) are described. Valiente links Pan to other horned deities like Dionysus and the Celtic Cernunnos, noting his worship involved nude dances and merriment. The concept of 'Great Pan was dead' is reinterpreted as the old pagan faith going underground, reappearing in the witch cult, which deeply connects with instinctive, merry, circling dances as a response to living Nature.

Explores the pentagram as a favorite symbol of witches and magicians, also known as a 'pentacle.' Its ancient origins are traced to Babylon and its presence in Christian architecture (Five Wounds of Christ), Freemasonry, and Qabalah (pentalpha, 'Druid's Foot'). The pentagram's five points represent the Four Elements plus Spirit, symbolizing 'Mind ruling over Matter' when pointed upwards, or 'Kali Yuga' when reversed. It is used to control elementals, for protection, and as the 'Star of the Microcosm,' representing humanity's five senses and inner potential, also called the 'Endless Knot' for its continuous drawing.

Details the horrific history of witch persecution, which Valiente argues was driven by religious heresy rather than actual harm. She contrasts England's hanging with Scotland's and Continental Europe's burning (often after torture). The text exposes Matthew Hopkins' profiteering and the brutality of witch-prickers, including cases like Alison Balfour, tortured with 'boots' and 'pilnie-winks.' It describes mob violence, drawing blood to 'break spells,' and the German 'witch-exorcist' practices. The repeal of the Witchcraft Act in 1736 and the modern persistence of accusations highlight the shift in legal and public opinion.

Discusses the ancient and natural reverence for the phallus and cteis/yoni as symbols of the life-force, without 'obscenity' in pre-Christian contexts (e.g., Sacred Lingam in India). Valiente explains how the Christian Church demonized this, depicting the Devil with prominent sexual organs. She connects witch rituals like the jumping dance with broomsticks to phallic fertility rites (Priapus statues). The text highlights the widespread use of phallic amulets for luck and protection (fascinum), and how descriptions of the Devil's 'cold penis' in Sabbat confessions likely refer to artificial phalli used in ancient rituals, now debased.

Explores the concept of Quintessence (Aether, Spirit) as the fifth element beyond earth, air, fire, and water, central to ancient occult philosophy. Valiente links it to the 'power' in magic and raises questions about its nature as energy or hypnotism. She highlights its universality in Eastern traditions (Tattvas) and Welsh Druidism (nyv), connecting it to modern atomic physics where matter and energy are interchangeable. The text discusses 'borderline energies' (dowsing, radiesthesia), Mesmer's 'animal magnetism,' the Kahunas' 'Mana,' and Lytton's 'Vril,' positioning the Emerald Tablet of Hermes Trismegistus as a cryptic message about this universal life energy, whose source is the sun.

Discusses reincarnation as an ancient, widespread belief, evident in modern England and in the 'Old Religion' of Western Europe. Valiente cites Charles Godfrey Leland's documentation of its survival among Italian witches and connects it to Druidic teachings (Abred, Gwynvyd), Pythagorean philosophy, and Ovid/Virgil. The text highlights how early Christianity gradually suppressed this doctrine in favor of fixed afterlife concepts (heaven/hell) to maintain social order. The pagan concept of the triple goddess of Fate (Moirai, Nornir) is linked to reincarnation, offering an alternative view of destiny and soul evolution rooted in ancient mythology.

Addresses ritual murder as a dark aspect of black magic, citing modern cases like the Manson family killings (Sharon Tate) and historical examples. Valiente explains it as a means to gain power from a sacrificed victim's 'life-force.' She notes its primitive religious origins (Old Testament human sacrifice, Divine King concept) and ancient practices like foundation sacrifices (Roman forts, infants). The text describes the cult of Thugs (Kali worship) and cannibalism for 'soul-substance.' Modern Satanist cults using plastic dolls and fake blood are discussed, alongside the Zodiac killer, highlighting the dangerous blend of occultism and hallucinogenic drugs.

Explores historical links between British royalty and witchcraft. Valiente discusses King William Rufus ('Red King') as an open pagan, his death at Lammas as a ritual sacrifice. She suggests Plantagenet kings, particularly Edward III, favored the Old Religion, connecting the Order of the Garter's origin to a 'witch-garter.' The Black Prince and Richard II's symbols are also linked to paganism. The author discusses Margaret Murray's theory of ritual killing of kings and Elizabeth Woodville's marriage as an 'Old Religion' ceremony, highlighting how accusations of witchcraft often served political motives while reflecting genuine ancient beliefs.

Details the eight Sabbats (four Greater: Candlemas, May Eve, Lammas, Halloween; four Lesser: solstices, equinoxes) as key festivals in the witch's year, aligned with Celtic Druidic traditions. Valiente describes them as occasions for dancing, feasting, invoking Old Gods, and performing magical work, often held outdoors with bonfires or indoors with altars. She discusses the origin of 'Sabbat' from Sabadius/Dionysus (god of ecstasy) and the controversial 'no salt' rule, interpreting it as a rejection of social distinctions. Historical accounts from Somerset and Northumberland describe these gatherings, often misrepresented by witch-hunters, but revealing genuine pagan elements like communal enjoyment and magical practice.

Defines scrying as the practice of obtaining clairvoyance by gazing into a 'speculum' (e.g., crystal globe, black bowl, glass fishing-floats). Valiente explains how witches improvise specula to avoid detection during persecution. She details Dr. Dee's 'shew-stone' and the process of making a magic mirror (black-backed glass, consecrated at full moon). Instructions for scrying involve relaxation, dim light, incense, and interpreting both objective and subjective visions. The author shares personal experiences of accurate scrying, including seeing an X-shaped cross symbolizing crossed letters and visualizing a pagan ritual site, noting Leland's descriptions of Italian water scrying.

Profiles Montague Summers as a mysterious and picturesque scholar of witchcraft, who, despite being a devout Roman Catholic, believed in the Devil and witches as his servitors. Valiente acknowledges his meticulous scholarship and extensive translations of older works (e.g., 'Malleus Maleficarum'), which greatly contributed to the literature of witchcraft. The text mentions his private chapel, his physical appearance, and his belief that Brighton held a secret black magic center, also noting his writings on vampires and werewolves as associated with witchcraft.

Explores Tarot cards as popular divination tools containing mystical and magical secrets. Valiente traces their preservation among gypsies and witches, citing Grillot de Givry on their use by village witches. The structure of the 78-card deck, including Major Arcana and four suits (Wands, Cups, Swords, Coins/Pentacles), is explained, with the suits corresponding to the 'Four Elemental Weapons' and the Celtic 'Four Treasures of the Tuatha De Danaan.' The author connects the Tarot's symbolism to the Qabalistic Tree of Life and discusses different versions (Marseilles, Waite/Smith, Crowley's 'Book of Thoth'), noting the Horned God's appearance as 'the Devil' and the Wheel of Fortune as the yearly cycle.

Details the horrific use of torture in witch trials, driven by the Church's belief in witchcraft as heresy against God. Valiente contrasts English law (torture unofficial) with Scottish and Continental practices, citing cases like Alison Balfour, subjected to 'boots' and 'pilnie-winks.' She describes the psychological torment (showing instruments) and physical brutality (boiling oil, strappado) used to extract confessions, often from children. The text highlights the financial motives of witch-hunters and the public celebrations of executions, noting the courage of figures like Father Friedrich Von Spee who spoke against these atrocities, and the eventual decline of torture due to widespread revulsion.

Explores the deep, pre-Christian connection between trees and witchcraft, describing trees as having distinct personalities and being abodes of spirits. Valiente discusses Elliott O'Donnell's 'tree cult' and stories of haunted woods (Tuck's Wood). The chapter highlights specific trees like the Witch of Hethel (an ancient thorn tree near a sacred site) and the symbolic importance of oak, ash, and thorn in the 'Fairy Triad.' Customs like 'Touch wood' and the Christmas tree (as a miniature 'World Tree') are presented as relics of ancient tree worship, and 'witches' brooms' (fungal growths) are seen as signs of uncanny influence.

Discusses UFOs in the context of ancient and medieval sky phenomena, linking them to witchcraft. Valiente mentions Pliny's 'flying shield' and the legend of 'Magonia,' an unearthly city in the clouds whose inhabitants were believed to be allied with witches to cause storms. The 10th-century Archbishop Agobard of Lyons's rational denunciation of these beliefs is highlighted. The text also mentions 'fire-drakes' (fiery clouds) observed in past centuries, drawing parallels to modern UFO sightings and suggesting a continuity in human interpretation of strange aerial phenomena.

structure_content.chapter_title: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, WITCHCRAFT IN PRESENT-DAY
structure_content.summary: Examines the active presence of witchcraft in the USA, noting its historical links to European traditions and mingling with American voodoo. Valiente highlights Roy Heist's occult supply business and Vance Randolph's research on Ozark Mountain witchcraft, which included naked rites for crops and initiation by opposite-sex blood relatives. Pennsylvania Dutch 'hex signs' for protection are discussed, along with the Salem witch trials as an early example of persecution. The text critically addresses modern 'Satanist' cults that conflate witchcraft with devil-worship and Manson's influence, contrasting them with serious American witches combating misrepresentation, and noting collective psychic efforts for peace (Vietnam War).

Explores 'The Upright Man' as a figure from old English beggar brotherhoods, identified as the male leader of a witch coven in ancient times. Valiente connects this role to the Devil in witch covens, who represented the Horned God and presided over fertility rites. The text details his authority within the 'Canting Crew' (vagabonds), his right to Doxies (women), and his role in 'Stalling to the Rogue' initiations. This figure is presented as a clear descendant of the 'Old Religion,' surviving clandestinely among society's outcasts, maintaining strong links to pagan traditions of sexual emphasis and ritual leadership.

Examines the belief in vampires, tracing its Slavonic origins ('wampyr') and historical presence in Britain (pre-1823 custom of burying unhallowed dead at crossroads with a stake). Valiente discusses occult theories of vampirism as an evil spirit animating a corpse or a dead soul clinging to its body, draining vitality. The text references the 'Vampire of Croglin Grange' and links witch bodies to becoming vampires after death. It details a 1732 official investigation in Servia (Arnod Paole), where vampire corpses were exhumed and burned, highlighting the contagious aspect of vampirism. The chapter concludes by distinguishing psychopathic cases from a dangerous 'vitality-draining' form of black magic.

Investigates the belief in werewolves as a traditional power of black witchcraft, achieved through stripping, anointing with magical unguents, and wearing enchanted belts. Valiente explains the occult theory of werewolfery as a transformation of the astral body, citing Algernon Blackwood and Eliphas Levi on the phenomenon of 'repercussion' (wounds on astral body manifesting on physical). The Old Norse term 'ham-farir' (traveling in assumed animal shape) is presented as evidence of its antiquity. The text discusses lycanthropy as a mental sickness and historical trials in France and Germany, linking werewolf powers to witchcraft and possible origins in cannibalistic rites or ancient cults (Zeus Lycaeus, Odin's berserks).

Describes 'witch balls' as bright, reflecting glass globes found in antique shops, traditionally used to avert the Evil Eye by reflecting malign glances. Valiente distinguishes these from Nailsea glass balls (multi-colored swirls, also for diverting evil) and older hollow glass spheres filled with threads, which created a mazy pattern. She explains the belief that witch balls attracted ill luck, necessitating periodic cleaning. The text notes their use for inducing hypnosis and their evolution from magical protective amulets to mere decorations, highlighting their enduring symbolic significance despite forgotten origins.

Defines witchcraft as 'Wisecraft,' an Anglo-Saxon term ('wicca/wicce') meaning 'wise one,' distinct from later demonized interpretations. Valiente emphasizes that it's a religion, philosophy, and way of life, not merely an intellectual pursuit, but one that values emotions, physical senses, and spiritual development through 'five states of human consciousness.' She refutes associations with Satanism and Black Mass, tracing the latter's creation to Church propaganda. The text discusses the fragmented nature of the Old Religion, its oral transmission, the secrecy of the 'Book of Shadows,' and the practice of lone witches with private shrines, concluding that witchcraft is a living, evolving tradition that promotes acceptance and freedom, guided by the principle 'Do what you will, so long as it harms none.'

Details the 'witches' ladder,' a traditional curse object described in folklore, consisting of a three-stranded rope with feathers (often from male birds) knotted into it. Valiente cites a 1886 'Folklore Journal' find in Somerset and Charles Godfrey Leland's discovery of similar Italian charms ('guirlanda delle streghe'). The text explains its use for inflicting pain or misfortune by knotting aches and pains into the cord. The magical number three is significant in its construction, and the feathers symbolize sending the spell flying, highlighting a widespread, ancient, and secret form of witchcraft.

Recounts a strange modern witch story from Essex during WWII, involving a witch buried at 'Scrapfaggot Green' under a stone. When a bulldozer moved the stone for road widening, a series of poltergeist events occurred (scaffolding scattered, paint pots hidden, straw ricks tumbled, church bells ringing). Valiente describes these as extraordinary but witnessed happenings, suggesting they were caused by the disturbance of the witch's grave. The events ceased when the stone was replaced, implying a placated spirit, illustrating the enduring local belief in witchcraft's power and its connection to specific sites.

Explores the cross as an ancient, pre-Christian religious symbol of great antiquity, transcending its Christian meaning. Valiente details various forms (Latin, Greek, Swastika, Tau, Celtic) and their widespread occurrence (Pre-Columbian Mexico, Minoan Crete). The equal-armed cross symbolizes the union of masculine and feminine forces (Yang/Yin) and the Four Elements plus the Quintessence. The Fylfot Cross (Swastika) is discussed as a sign of light and beneficence, historically used on church bells to dispel storms, highlighting the cross as a universal pagan and Christian emblem for good fortune and protection.

Explains Yule as the Anglo-Saxon word for the winter solstice, representing a composite of Celtic (Alban Arthan), Roman (Saturnalia), and Saxon traditions later adapted into Christmas. Valiente notes customs like cutting mistletoe, the York Minster 'universal liberty' proclamation, and the Saturnalia's revelry (feasting, gift-giving, social inversion). The Yule Log symbolizes ancient blazing fires and the 'Great Wheel of the Zodiac.' Modern witches celebrate Yule as a Nature festival, recognizing the rebirth of the sun and the beginning of winter (Horned God's domain), with evergreens symbolizing life and mumming plays enacting the sun's triumph over darkness.

Discusses the zodiac as a source of the witches' number thirteen (lunar months plus sun/moon) and its ancient, possibly unknown, origin. Valiente interprets 'zoidiakos' as 'figure of Life' or 'image of the course of Life,' representing universal life. The zodiac's division into twelve signs, ruled by planets, reflects influences on human beings. She highlights the Glastonbury Zodiac, a geoglyphic landscape formation, discovered by Mrs. K. E. Maltwood, depicting a pre-Christian planisphere linked to Arthurian legends. Dr. John Dee's diaries suggest knowledge of this zodiac, supporting the idea of a secret, ancient tradition worthy of study beyond mere superstition.

key_concepts.definition: Valiente's term for the ancient, pre-Christian nature worship of Western Europe, which she asserts is the true origin of witchcraft, suppressed and demonized by the Church but surviving clandestinely. It centers on the worship of the Horned God and Moon Goddess, fertility rites, and communal gatherings.

An ancient, pan-cultural deity representing the masculine, active side of Nature, fertility, vitality, and the cycles of life and death. Often depicted with horns (e.g., Pan, Cernunnos), he was later demonized by the Christian Church and conflated with the Devil, becoming the male leader of witch covens in ritual disguise.

The feminine principle of Nature, revered in various forms (e.g., Diana, Artemis, Hecate, Isis), associated with fertility, magic, and the moon's three phases (waxing, full, waning). She is often seen as the primordial creatrix and the mistress of enchantment, ruling over the tides, human fertility, and the psychic realm.

One of the eight major yearly festivals in the witch's calendar, rooted in ancient Celtic and pagan observances (e.g., Samhain/Halloween, Beltane/May Eve, Lammas, Candlemas). These gatherings involve ritual dancing, feasting, invoking deities, and magical workings, often held outdoors at sacred sites like stone circles or hills, representing a communion with natural cycles.

A monthly meeting of a witch's coven, typically held at the full moon. These are less formal than Sabbats and are used for various purposes, including conducting coven business, practicing minor magic, divination, celebrating, and fostering community among members. Rituals may involve dancing, invocations, and sharing of food and drink.

A ritual space drawn to protect the practitioner from hostile forces and to concentrate magical energy or 'power' within. It is typically oriented to the cardinal points, often with symbolic objects or lights, and drawn with an athame. It symbolizes infinity, eternity, and the universe, serving as a focal point for ritual work.

The traditional black-handled knife used by witches, not for cutting or physical harm, but for directing magical energy, drawing the magic circle, and controlling spirits. Its origins are traced to ancient daggers used in ritual, symbolizing the male principle or directing will.

A spirit helper of a witch, manifesting in one of three forms: a discarnate human spirit, a non-human elemental, or a material animal (e.g., cat, toad). Familiars aid in magical workings, divination, and conveying influence, often forming a psychic link with the witch through shared blood or milk. They possess acute psychic perceptions.

A trance-inducing unguent traditionally used by witches to create hallucinatory experiences of astral flight to Sabbats or other places. Composed of various narcotic herbs (e.g., henbane, mandrake, deadly nightshade), it was believed to enable out-of-body travel and visionary experiences, providing a physiological basis for the legends of witches flying.

An Eastern doctrine meaning 'action,' implying that every action generates an appropriate reaction, which may manifest in the current or subsequent lives. Valiente presents this as a concept also present in Western beliefs (Fate, Destiny, Wyrd), influencing the understanding of reincarnation and the unfolding of one's life experiences.

The belief that the human soul passes through multiple lifetimes, evolving with each incarnation. Witches believe the soul rests in the 'Land of Faery' between lives. This concept provides an alternative to Christian notions of heaven and hell, and aligns with the cyclical nature of the 'Old Religion,' where lessons are learned and destiny ('weird') is fulfilled.

The Fifth Element, also known as Aether or Spirit, representing a subtle, universal life energy or 'power' that underpins the four physical elements (earth, air, fire, water). Occultists and witches believe this energy can be raised and directed through magical practices. Valiente connects it to modern concepts like 'orgone energy' (Wilhelm Reich) and ancient texts like the Emerald Tablet of Hermes Trismegistus, as the fundamental source of manifestation.

practical_system.description: Valiente's system of witchcraft is presented as the 'Old Religion,' a nature-based spiritual path emphasizing harmony with cosmic forces. It is operative magic, driven by the practitioner's will, concentration, and innate psychic capacities. The system centers on working with the Horned God (masculine, active life force) and the Moon Goddess (feminine, passive, mysterious life force), who are personified aspects of Divine Nature. Rituals aim to raise 'power' for various purposes, from personal development to influencing external events, always guided by the ethical principle of 'An it harm none, do what ye will.' The practice integrates elements of astrology, numerology, herbalism, divination, and communal or solitary rites, often involving altered states of consciousness induced by rhythmic activity or unguents.
tools: Athame: Black-handled ritual knife for directing energy and drawing the magic circle.
Magic Circle: A demarcated ritual space for protection and power concentration.
Altar: A central focal point within the magic circle, often containing candles, incense, and other ritual objects.
Wand/Staff: Used for directing energy, sometimes a forked staff ('Bune Wand') for flight symbolism.
Censer: For burning incense, used to create magical atmosphere and provide form for evoked spirits.
Cauldron: Symbol of transformation, rebirth, and the feminine principle, used in ritual cooking or brewing potions.
Book of Shadows: A personal grimoire for recording rituals, spells, and magical knowledge.
Amulets & Talismans: Objects (e.g., holed stones, horse brasses, cimaruta, pentagrams) imbued with power for protection or to attract specific benefits.
Scrying Tools: Reflecting surfaces like black mirrors, crystal balls, glass fishing-floats, or blue glass bottles for clairvoyance.
Herbs: Various plants and their specific magical (e.g., mugwort for clairvoyance, foxglove for healing) and medicinal properties.
Candles: Used for illumination, specific magical intent (colored candles), and communication with spirits (flame interpretation).
rituals: Sabbats: Eight seasonal festivals (e.g., Halloween/Samhain, May Eve/Beltane, solstices, equinoxes) celebrating natural cycles, involving dancing, feasting, and invoking deities, often with bonfires and ritual nudity.
Esbats: Monthly meetings at the full moon for coven business, minor magical workings, divination, and communal enjoyment, utilizing a magic circle and various tools.

Magic Circle Construction: Drawing a protective and power-concentrating circle, typically nine feet in diameter, oriented to cardinal points, with an altar at its center. This is done with an athame, often with outer pentagrams.

Invocations & Evocations: Invoking higher deities into the magic circle to raise consciousness, and evoking lower spirits into a triangle outside the circle for specific commands, using 'Words of Power' and specific herbs.
Divination: Practices like scrying (gazing into mirrors or crystal balls), interpreting symbols (tea leaves, Tarot cards), and using familiars to gain hidden knowledge or foretell the future.

Love Charms: Spells and potions using herbs (e.g., marsh St. John's wort, verbena), personal items, and focused intent to attract love, sometimes involving ritual nudity or symbolic actions ('cockle-bread').

Healing: Herbal remedies ('wortcunning') for physical ailments and psychological techniques (like hypnosis) to influence health, drawing on ancient knowledge passed through generations of 'wise women'.

relevant_quotes.text: 'Do what you will, so long as it harms none.'

Witchcraft is as old as the human race. It dates from the days when, by the flickering light of a clay lamp, a Stone Age artist worked in the silent depths of a cave sanctuary, drawing upon the walls the great beasts he hunted for his food.

The magic of the caves was concerned with primal things: life and death. In order to live, primitive man had to master the great beasts, to hunt and kill them. But unless there were many young born to the beasts, the herds would fail, and man would go hungry. Unless the women of his tribe were fertile, in those days when life was precarious and its expectation short, mans species too would lose its hold upon the world. So man made magic for life as well as hunting.

critical_analysis.relevance: Doreen Valiente's 'An ABC of Witchcraft Past and Present' is a seminal work in modern Western Esotericism, particularly for the Wiccan tradition. It serves as a comprehensive, sympathetic encyclopedia, offering a crucial counter-narrative to historical demonization of witchcraft. Valiente's insider perspective, combined with meticulous research, provides a foundation for understanding witchcraft as a genuine, nature-based religion, distinct from Satanism. Her work directly influenced the development of Gardnerian Wicca and continues to inform eclectic pagan practices, solidifying key concepts like the Horned God, Moon Goddess, Sabbats, and the ethical 'An it harm none, do what ye will.' It's highly relevant for its historical revisionism, practical insights into ritual mechanics, and its contribution to the mainstream acceptance and understanding of contemporary paganism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes both novice and experienced practitioners of witchcraft, Wicca, and other pagan traditions seeking a deeper, authoritative understanding of their practices. It also caters to academic researchers in Western Esotericism, religious studies, anthropology, and folklore who desire a scholarly yet sympathetic overview. Additionally, it appeals to general readers interested in occultism, spirituality, or counter-cultural movements who wish to explore witchcraft beyond sensationalized stereotypes. Valiente's clear explanations and practical focus make it accessible for self-study and a valuable reference for anyone engaging with the operative side of magic.
